title: 5 Year & $650+ Account Permabanned Because of AFK Duo
body:
(This is not the account banned, as I found out those accounts cannot post on boards, it redirects to an error page.)

So I have been chat banned before, which is okay. Only once in 5 years, actually. I have always been the type to get mad, usually when I am flamed first. So around a month or two ago, I was chat banned, then banned for 14 days. In both instances I was _responding_ to flame, not instigating. Both times it was because a duo flamed and reported me, rather than a single person. Very few times have I been told the person I reported was punished, but here I am, all at once. This is obviously due to the new robot system they use to pick out the flamers, but it didn't acknowledge the afk person or anything they said. 

Mostly what led to the report was him calling me adopted and me responding by calling him an autist. Now, I don't condone this behavior at all, but a logical response to being flamed is to flame back. It is human nature. But when the report system is based on just someone being rude to you, why is there a mute option? If muting removes all hostility chat-wise, why is it a reportable offense? I have been playing for five years and had over $600 dollars in this game, but now it is all to waste. It was my birthday yesterday and I bought myself Star Guardian Jinx today for my me-celebration. But a natural, human response to me being provoked led to a permanent ban. I could keep playing on a new account, which would be completely fine. However, I now lose more than half a thousand dollars, prompting me to write this.

I am specifically targeting the new system, or _Instant Feedback_, as Riot calls it. In real life, are instant, unresearched answers ever better than a thought-out, methodical approach? No. And I am aware there are too many players to go through. For a perma-ban, I do not think an instant system should be in use, and as much as I would like to plead for a case reviewal, I am aware Riot takes no time or effort for this kind of thing, as I researched the topic and found that many had asked Riot and pleaded to no avail, with one even having Riot Lyte respond. I am aware that due to the terms I, and we all, agreed to that I have no legal right to my account or the money value attached to it, but I do believe it should not be completely wasted. If I could choose another account to send it it to, it'd be great. Of course that would mean that there are no consequences, but what if I split it up between several friends? It is really the monetary issue bothering me.

I get that toxicity is bad. So put emphasis on the mute button, not a perma-ban for a 5 year account. With such a toxic community, one would think it would make more sense to address the issue, not every player infected by it. Imagine how many people would be banned if every person was being scanned by this algorithm at the same time. I know it would be a massive percentage, since I only have 3 offenses, and many have many more. Riot has essentially sided with the person who flames first, acts like a victim, and has a buddy with them to report with him.

I assume that there are many players who can relate to this, and I hope they respond. It is a natural thing. Riot is essentially telling us to remove our thought of freedom of speech and targeting anyone who has even mild anger issues.

I believe it would be better to have an actual in depth review on who flamed who and who the blame should be on, in the case of a perma-ban. I have no closure since it was a robot who decided me being reported by two people was a better choice than banning the person reported by only one person. They probably feel great that I was punished, but it could have just been me having an off day or, as mentioned before, just having natural human response. I would personally like to petition Riot to reconsider and revamp the ban system, especially for perma-bans, even if it does not affect the status of my beloved account.

So, finally, I am likely going to bring this to a close by calling this my official resignation letter from League of Legends. I apologize for not being the perfect role model who has only had 3 offenses recognized by Riot in 5 years, which is apparently enough to have an algorithm ban me forever.

This is why I want the tribunal back.  Having multiple people review the chat logs in each game you were reported in leading up to your ban ensures that the context of each situation is considered.  When you have people reporting each other left and right you need an actual person to decide who is actually at fault and not a machine.
If there are three people flaming each other and being toxic in chat, they are all at fault regardless of who started it. One person's extreme toxicity does not excuse another person's mild toxicity.

Which is for the tribunal to decide.  I had 100% accuracy in my verdicts using the tribunal.  I know a toxic player when I see it and honestly, I saw a lot of stupid reports in the tribunal.  A lot of people get reported for maybe being a little rude for 2 comments in defense of themselves or someone else and that's it.

>A lot of people get reported for maybe being a little rude for 2 comments in defense of themselves or someone else and that's it.

I think there are two things going on here:

* It's never okay to respond to toxicity with more toxicity. If you can defend yourself without causing more toxicity, that's cool.
 

* The IFS doesn't just say "hey, there's some toxicity here. **WHAM, TAKE THAT BAN AND LIKE IT!!!!** While the context of the toxicity is irrelevant, the IFS takes the frequency and intensity of the toxicity into consideration, along with account history.

I said rude, I didn't necessarily say toxic.  Here is an example.  Someone is flaming a teammate for having a bad game and I respond to them with something along the lines of "you are just too good for us to be on your level."

Would you consider such a statement to be toxic?

I consider it unnecessary, but it's not toxic by itself. On the other hand, just having a spat in chat can be toxic. In the days of the Tribunal, there was a strong correlation between number of lines of text and likelihood of punishment. People don't care for arguments and rightfully so. They want everyone to concentrate on the game.

I like how you're getting downvoted despite the fact that you're being reasonable.  

What used to be so appealing about League of Legends was that the community set the standard for what was acceptable behavior.  I had a 95% Tribunal accuracy with around 6,000 cases... In almost all of them, the instigator would be punished.  I had numerous cases in which someone would report the guy that finally cracked and said "fuck you" as a single response (or maybe a couple of lines of response) and invariably, that person would be overwhelmingly voted "Don't Punish".  

I can't tell you how many games I see someone get absolutely destroyed in chat for making a mistake or, often, not playing the way someone thinks they should and after 25 minutes of this I might chime in and say "hey, just leave them alone already, shut up and play" -- is that toxic?  maybe, but when I started playing this game that was what the community thought was an appropriate response.  

Players policing themselves, not some silly computer that is easily outwitted by 10 year olds to avoid saying the "keywords" that get them banned.  It's pretty easy to outsmart a machine, much harder to outsmart an entire community.

Nice that you would share your own accuracy before attacking Riot's current system. And with such a convenient number, too.

The current system had roughly an error every 1 in 6000 punishments, as opposed to your 300. And that was when it was still being calibrated.

Also: The blanket statement that a "silly computer" can be outwitted is extremely ignorant. The system neither uses specific keywords, nor does it exclusively ban people who are younger than 10 years old. People regularly come onto the forums to complain about being punished despite not using any "bad words".

Speaking of convenient numbers---how do you know that the error rate is 1-in-6000?  Because Riot told you so?  If their system was so incredible then there would be far fewer instances of toxicity in this game, period.  

It's not ignorant to say that the current system can be outwitted.  Any system that is primarily devoid of human oversight can be easily circumvented.  I won't link the Summoner here (due to name-and-shame rules), but there is an individual that feeds intentionally every five games or so and has participated in that activity since 2015... I've played a game with this person and they openly laughed in the post game about "reports doing nothing", while looking at that individual's match history it was very clear to see that they had been doing this every few games for two or more years.  

In the Tribunal system, that individual would have been easily punished by the community, but because of how this person intentionally feeds they are clearly beating the system.  

I've played with exceptionally toxic people who are still playing today.  I have numerous profiles of the worst offenders saved.  This also includes profiles of easily to spot MMR boosted accounts.  The garbage automated system doesn't catch that either.  

Now, you can say "but but but, what about the people that come to the Boards that ARE banned", in nearly every case they claim innocence but looking at their chat logs they all use the same key words, calling another player a sexually pejorative term, using racial slurs, etc.  Once in a while you'll see the guy that just spams the same messages 300 times in a game and is banned for that... all very easy algorithms for a machine to pick up on.  Passive-aggressive play or the issues I mentioned above are clearly not detected by Riot's neat gizmos, and subsequently, human oversight is required, period.

How do I know you have 95% accuracy in Tribunal?
Frankly, you have more reason to lie about it than Riot. Why would Riot go with an objectively worse system and then lie about how good it actually is? Besides, what evidence do you have that would suggest it's false? It's rare to find a "real" unjust case on the forums... and you'd think that people who actually know that they are innocent would be more likely to come here to complain.

Btw: That 1 in 6000 is the false positive rate, which is a measure of specificity. My bad, should have specified that. But I feel like specificity is the more important subject given that OP claims to have been unjustly punished.
Deterring people from being toxic (or removing them from the community) on the other hand requires a high sensitivity.
Those are two entirely different (and often conflicting) attributes. Depending on whether you want to look at the sensitivity per case or the sensitivity "per time" the Tribunal was also way worse in this aspect, since it took ages to actually punish people.

There's definitely a problem with automated detection of feeding... But Tribunal had similar problems since people often simply lacked the information to accurately determine whether or not somebody was intentionally feeding.
But once again, this is a different subject. You were clearly talking about chat toxicity, as otherwise you wouldn't have mentioned keywords.

And once again: People **do** get banned for sarcasm and passive aggressive behaviour. You focus on what is easy for a machine to pick up and directly assume that it is the **only** think it can pick up. And that is exactly why I called you ignorant. The most critical part of your entire argument is backed up by nothing but handwaving.

You have no evidence as to the accuracy of your assessment.  You have the word of the company that has repeatedly provided false information, or more aptly, lied to it's customers regarding various other projects.  Quite infamously, of course, is where they said that reverse camera implementation would take place in a "couple weeks" in 2009.  Let's not even get into everything about solo queue from last season, the equally infamous Warwick update from 2012 or other well documented and chronicled misleading statements Riot has provided.  

I think most importantly is that they stated the Tribunal would return in 2014/2015 and it never did... 

If someone is willing to lie to you about one thing, what is to make you believe them regarding something else?  Maybe they're telling you the truth, maybe they're not, but I think the best way to demonstrate how effective their system happens to be is simply by experiencing it yourself.  

I challenge anyone to play 20 normal draft games of Summoner's Rift (or ranked for that matter) in any MMR under Master tier (I say under master tier because you're likely to get different players every game) and see how many games/players violate the Summoner's code.  

In the last year, I have reported someone in AT LEAST 25% of my games.  

If this system was so effective, why are intentional feeders still occurring?  Why am I told to "kys" several times a week, why am I encountering someone that says "good job" after someone on their own team gives up first blood?  I see this with a fair degree of frequency, far more than I ever did when I started playing in 2011.  Sure, there are more players now than back then, but your magical machine-learning technology that you so vigorously and seemingly blindly defend as the panacea is CLEARLY not working... or is inefficient and only eliminates extreme cases.  

There is no counter argument to that, period.

This, precisely this, is why Riot is among the very few companies that are willing to communicate with their playerbase directly, rather than through the proxy of PR experts.
Every wrong ETA, every honest mistake, every change of mind is turned into a lie by people like you.

And you still keep trying to diver the discussion. How effective the system is was never the point. The question is how effective it is compared to Tribunal. And your personal memory of how it used to be does little to show that, given how prone to bias personal memory is.

And once again: There's no counter argument to that, because it's a handwaving argument. Anecdotal evidence followed by the statement that something is "clearly" the case has no substance that could be countered.

I mean how about you try to counter the following argument:
I personally remember toxicity being worse during Tribunal times. So CLEARLY the current system is working better.
